question: Can you? Really? You?
answer: Mr. Clyde. I don't see this helping.

question: No? You married? Children?
answer: Divorced. I have a son and daughter. Both in college.

question: We don't do chair. We do needle. Whoa, Jonas, take my elbow. *
answer: I'm not blind. Yet. I'll do it.

question: You're shitty on stairs. At least let me take the leash so the dog doesn't pull you down.
answer: No. She needs to imprint on me. Not you, not somebody else. That's the whole point of this phase. She needs to get the idea that she and I are partners. Then the real training can begin. Unless you wanna lead me around the rest of my life.

question: Hellooo, kettle to pot. Since when do you shy away from publicity?
answer: Since everything in this case has gone sideways so far. Tell your boy to save it for the courtroom.

question: He's your boy too now. You tell him.
answer: Asshole.

question: breaks the handshake with a flush of discomfort, signals the federal marshal: Marshal, escort your man, please! Mr. Darby is done here!
answer: Shit day?

question: Shit day. Better now. How's she doing?
answer: Fine. She drove me a little crazy today.

question: She was busy?
answer: In overdrive. Here. Feel. Of course she stops kicking the moment you get home.

question: I had to say some things to a man today I didn't want to say. And I did something I didn't want to do.
answer: You didn't lie to him. Or bullshit him. Or shine him on.

question: None of those things.
answer: So you had your reasons. You did what you had to. It's not your fault the world sucks.

question: You in there. Listen up. Your mother just said the world sucks. You may wanna rethink this whole thing. My advice? If you're asking? Just stay in there. I promise you, nothing will ever make as much sense as it does right now...
answer: What is wrong with you?

question: ...plus there's shit you don't need to know about. Rap. Internet porn. Madonna's entire back catalog.
answer: Did someone drop you on your head? Seriously. I have swollen ankles and all I do is pee. That baby's coming out.

question: Okay. I'm sure you heard that. Then again there are the Beatles. 70's funk. Louie. Ella. Be a shame to miss those. All right, kid. Bring it on. But when you're old enough for the world to disappoint you, I hope you won't blame your old man for bringing you into this mess. Give me that at least.
answer: Dad?

question: Huh? Wha--?
answer: You know what it is?

question: What?
answer: IT'S MY BIRTHDAAAAAY! IT'S MY BIRTHDAY, IT'S MY BIRTHDAY, IT'S MY BIRTHDAY! I'M SO COOL IT'S MY BIRTHDAAAY!

question: Why can't you be here?
answer: It's a work thing. Grownup stuff. You know that happens sometimes.

question: But it's... ...MY BIRTHDAAAAAY!
answer: I believe we've established that. I let go, you'll stop reminding me? We'll celebrate this weekend. Tonight is all about your friends. Knock * yourselves out, don't give mom any * grief. I'll try to be home in time to tuck you in, okay?

question: Wait...wait... Almost. Almost.
answer: This shit makes you soft, baby.

question: Thank you...for stating the obvious...you...bitch... "Did not go well." Way to go, Rupert. You even fucked up dying.
answer: You know that guy?

question: Knew. Past tense.
answer: Wayne?

question: Depends. Who's this?
answer: Somebody who doesn't want to see you in jail. Look out your window. Argue later. Do it now.

question: lowers the binoculars, stunned.
answer: There's a world of shit coming your way. I'd get out the back. Now.

question: Ditch the gun. Wipe the prints.
answer: Kiss my ass.

question: I heard six shots. Revolver? Bring extra ammo? You shot at cops. That's attempted murder if they find the gun on you. You're in deep enough without that. You'll need my help getting out.
answer: What'll it cost me?

question: We'll discuss terms later. Go south, across 10th. Past the El tracks. Alley behind the clinic.
answer: What's there?

question: A cop. Take his ride, he won't give * you any trouble.
answer: How do you know?

question: In the ditch.
answer: ...please...don't kill me...

question: Knees. Let's go.
answer: I'll never see my wife and little girl again. I'll never see them.

question: It's fucked up. This my guardian angel? Hello?
answer: I see you got out okay. You know why I'll never see my wife and daughter again?

question: Funny for her. I cleaned it up.
answer: I had my "ewwww gross" moment last night too.

question: Hey. I had a house full of shrieking ten year-old girls.
answer: Hey. I saw a guy's veins dissolve.

question: Counselor.
answer: Mr. Clyde.

question: Why so formal? We go way back. Call me Benson. Or Ben.
answer: Well. I'm here. So?

question: So. Maybe you can explain what this is all about.
answer: I think that's obvious.

question: Darby? I knew about Ames, of course. I've been following the news about his horribly botched execution. But Darby too? Quite a coincidence.
answer: Cut the shit. We know you did it. Save everybody a lot of time and trouble and just confess.

question: Are you going to continue to insist on being part of this conversation?
answer: Yes.

question: Unless there's hard evidence tying me to these crimes -- forensic or otherwise -- why am I here? Why are we having this conversation?
answer: We know you did it.

question: It's not about what you know. It's about what you can prove in court. Your words. Like when you called it a justice system. You know the thing about a system, Nick? Any system can be played.
answer: You think you can play us? You gonna take me on?

question: Clarence Darby did. And I'm much smarter than he was. Or you.
answer: I'm gonna bury you, fucker!

question: Or. Set me free.
answer: What?

question: Did I stutter? Make your case. Or. Shake my hand on the courthouse steps and send me on my way. I'll even make it easy on you. I will confess, how's that?
answer: You're gonna confess.

question: Let's start tomorrow after a good night's sleep. We'll all be fresh and rested.
answer: Confession or not, we're gonna nail him on two counts of first-degree.

question: Confession or not, we're gonna nail him on two counts of first-degree.
answer: Agreed, but softly. Nothing hard- ass, no grand-standing. Kid gloves.

question: Kid gloves? He's a psycho with a power saw.
answer: Depending on who's writing the headline, he's a grieving husband and father who got revenge on the men who murdered his wife and child. Public sympathy is to be respected and feared. This could blow up in our faces if we're not careful. We can't look like we're pissed off or have an ax to grind. Are we pissed off? Do we have an ax to grind?

question: No.
answer: Then stop acting like it.

question: Right. Prison crowding. It's a problem.
answer: For the record

question: We'll get to that. First, what I'd really like to talk about is the cot in my cell. It's lumpy. Hardly any padding? Steel springs? Very uncomfortable?
answer: I know what lumpy means. Sorry to hear it. But we're not here to talk about prison conditions, we're here to talk about things you've done.

question: Start with things I haven't done. Like get any sleep last night. I said let's begin today fresh and * rested. You recall my words? * A bed in my cell.
answer: A bed. In your cell.

question: Yes, please. One of those Sleep- Matic adjustables. Those are best. *
answer: You want the variable temperature control too?

question: That would be nice.
answer: Anybody?

question: Switching the drugs was easy... I hacked the Fedex database, diverted the package to me, made the switch, sent the package on. It's automated tracking numbers moving millions of packages daily. Nobody's questioning who receives what, or why.
answer: And the prison phones?

question: Get a phone company uniform, hack the prison database, schedule an official visit. They'll wave you through the gate, like they did me. It's simple if you know how things work. It's a system. You learn how it works. You play it. Any system.
answer: I saw him die. That stuff burned his veins. He suffered terribly.

question: Score.
answer: Let's move on to Clarence Darby.

question: * Hey, you like music?
answer: * Very much. Why? *

question: How about my ipod and speaker dock?
answer: The player stays out here. You hand the remote to the on-duty guard every night at lights out. Those terms aren't negotiable.

question: I appreciate your compromise.
answer: You looking to get your ass kicked? By every inmate on this cellblock. You keep this up, they'll take it out on you. Harshly. Just trying to keep you alive in here. That's all.

question: I took his fingers with a bolt cutter. His toes with a pair of tin snips. His balls with a hacksaw... ...his penis with a box cutter. His skin with a filet knife. His teeth with pliers. His eyes...for those I used my fingers. Check the video I made. All that will match up. I kept him alive for an hour, give or take. Time it. What now?
answer: My office types it up, you sign.

question: How about a signing bonus? The small concessions you've made so far have kept my cooperation flowing...why not give me a reward for signing?
answer: You don't want to sign, don't sign. We've got you on videotape, we'll go to trial. In ten years, when your appeals are exhausted, I'll attend your execution. I'll make sure nobody tampers with the drugs.

question: Don't be such a hard-ass, Nick. I don't want much. Just a good meal. The food here? Sucks. No offense.
answer: What do you have in mind?

question: There's a place in town on Halston. La Traviata. Ever been? *
answer: It's a little above my pay grade.

question: You know it, don't you, Nick? *
answer: I've eaten there. So? *

question: They cater. Tonight, at 7 p.m., I * would like my meal delivered to my cell from La Traviata. With nice silverware, crisp linens...
answer: Not gonna happen.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I have no interest in making it happen. And you have nothing left to bargain with.

question: He's a tinkerer. Little inventions * and gizmos... ...he holds two dozen patents that have made him a lot of money the last ten years. He's invested a lot of it in real estate. Weird stuff.
answer: Weird how?

question: Properties with no real value. Around * airports, chemical plants. Stuff * nobody wants... He votes. He gives money to charity, mostly victim's funds... ...but he also gives a big chunk to macular research.
answer: He donates to eye research?

question: RPI. That's the charity you work with, isn't it?
answer: Huh. Strange.

question: That's the spirit, yes! It's on you now, Nick. It's your game to lose. Just don't screw up. You do, they'll scapegoat you. That's * how the justice system works. * Good call, Sam. Making me disappear was a bad idea. You couldn't have handled the blowback.
answer: Blowback? * You're insane.

question: See how insane you think this is. You're going to release me from this place with all charges dropped within twenty four hours...
answer: Or what?

question: Where are you?
answer: Million miles away. Sorry.

question: Don't be. This guy's really doing a number on your head, isn't he?
answer: Yeah. I guess he is. It's...killing his cellmate. I need that to make sense.

question: Why? Happens in prison all the time.
answer: Yeah, I know, but...we're not talking some gang-banger. This man is precise. Does things for a reason.

question: He's psycho. You said so yourself. We saw it on that video. Psychos don't need a reason, Nick. They're just psycho. Whatever. You'll figure it out. You * always do.
answer: Thanks. I'm a poor excuse, though. It's date night. You deserve better. Just wish you'd picked another * restaurant. *

question: This is our place. You love it here. * You should have said something... *
answer: Sam? What is it? Not far, maybe six blocks. I'm having dinner with my wife.

question: Sam? What is it? Not far, maybe six blocks. I'm having dinner with my wife.
answer: Two words

question: He's coming here?
answer: So I'm told. It's called inter-agency cooperation, but don't ask me what agency because I wouldn't know. This isn't even back-channels, this is Theseus in the fucking Labyrinth. I just blew thirty years' worth of favors today calling in this one chit. I hope it's worth it. *

question: What was Clyde? Some kind of spy?
answer: Spooks like me are a dime a dozen. Clyde was a brain. He ran a think- tank, inventing things for use in the field. Ways to kill people. You need to get rid of somebody. It's not a situation where you can get close. What do you do?

question: Ask Clyde?
answer: That's right. Ask Clyde. And he'd figure something out. Gizmos, strategy. He was good at it.

question: How good?
answer: You play chess?

question: Yeah. Tournament level in college, matter of fact.
answer: In my line, we use an aptitude profile based on chess. A tournament- level player like you can think five to eight steps ahead of an average player, did you know that? Me, I think about ten steps ahead, so I'd take you in a game.

question: What about Clyde?
answer: Off the charts. If you're eight steps ahead, he's twenty. Or fifty. He's already got the game won on the first move, you don't even know you're playing yet. This cellmate he killed? You think that was random? Bullshit. That was a pawn taken off the board. If I were you, I'd be trying to figure out what the move was.

question: I have been. Any thoughts?
answer: Top of my head? Was the cellmate ever connected with this case? Or with Clyde? Was anybody else in that facility? Guards? Cons? The janitor? Any connection at all, no matter how remote. Because if Clyde says he has things in play, he does.

question: Top of my head? Was the cellmate ever connected with this case? Or with Clyde? Was anybody else in that facility? Guards? Cons? The janitor? Any connection at all, no matter how remote. Because if Clyde says he has things in play, he does.
answer: Like what? He's locked up. What can he do?

question: You're an average chess player, aren't you?
answer: Actually, I kind of suck.

question: I can tell. But I like your tie.
answer: Thank you. Father's Day.

question: Let me talk to mom first. Sorry about date night.
answer: It's fine. You learn anything?

question: Thing or two.
answer: Nick?

question: Hey, I was thinking. Maybe you could pack an overnight bag for you and Emma in case you need to...you know...spend the night in a hotel. Or something.
answer: Why would we wanna do that?

question: No reason. It's like a fire-drill thing. You know. In case.
answer: Honey? What the hell are you doing?

question: It's okay, baby -- I'm fine, I promise. Go back to your game.
answer: Seriously, Nick. What the fuck.

question: Nothing. I got paranoid for no reason, that's all. I'm fine now. I can't believe I let that son of a bitch Clyde get to me like that.
answer: Are you in danger? Are we?

question: I want to see him.
answer: You're up early. Trouble sleeping?

question: It was a good bluff. But you're done. Fucking with my head. Scaring * my family half to death. Done.
answer: Amazing, isn't it? How primal that is. That pull? What a man is capable of when it comes to his family? *

question: Good night, Ben.
answer: Good night, Nick. Is it casual Friday? I've never seen you not wear a tie.

question: I want a phone in my cell. If I'm conducting my own defense, it would be useful. Also in case you and I need to be in touch, Nick.
answer: Fuck you.

question: Your twenty four hours are about up. In return for the phone, I'll extend you another twelve hours.
answer: If not?

question: We're not risking anything. Or letting him tear us down. You're not getting us to throw out the rules, like you. No way.
answer: I like rules. I've wanted you to follow them from the start. Like the one that says you prosecute a man who murders my family. So. Rules. A phone buys you another twelve hours. But if you haven't cut my deal and let me go by the deadline...

question: What? What then?
answer: I'll kill someone in this room.

question: Who?
answer: Eenie...meenie...miney...moe... ...my mother...told me...to pick...a person...and that...person...is...

question: Any word?
answer: She's in surgery now. They're saying she'll be okay.

question: Thank God. That's good.
answer: Good? You'll have to explain the good part, Nick. I'm missing it. This is crazy. What if something happened to you? What would I say to Emma? What would we do?

question: You didn't lose me. You won't. Does the school know we're pulling Emma out of class?
answer: I called, yeah, but -- I'd rather be here for Sarah when she wakes up. Nick -- and for you. I want to do something...

question: You are. Getting our daughter out of harm's way. And yourself. Detective. Will you escort my wife, please? There's not much time. I'll be there to see you off. Okay? Please? Sarah's fine. That's the good news.
answer: Oh, God, that's a relief... Miss Lowell is okay...she's okay... We've been getting calls from upstairs. The mayor's people. Someone from our office has to make a statement to the press. With Mr. Cantrell absent, the mayor wants you to do it.

question: Royce...how much petty cash do we have in the safe?
answer: I don't know...four thousand?

question: Give it to me. And your cell phone. I need to borrow it for a few days.
answer: What do you want me to tell the mayor? We in the D.A.'s office are still reeling from the events of this morning, as you can imagine. It's a tragic day for us...for our city...

question: I wanna see Sarah...
answer: Hey, hey...she's fine, don't be scared. That's not allowed. And there's no reason for it.

question: This sucks.
answer: I know.

question: Why do we have to go?
answer: 'Cause your mom wants to see a few Broadway shows. You gonna begrudge her that?

question: You're kinda full of shit, Dad.
answer: Okay, you're right. Maybe I am a little. But only a little. The part you can believe is that this is all going to be fine. Sarah, us. I mean it. Okay?

question: Okay.
answer: No credit cards. Too easy to track. Meals, hotel, whatever -- pay cash. I'll keep this. It can be traced. Use this one instead. Don't answer unless you see it's me. *

question: No credit cards. Too easy to track. Meals, hotel, whatever -- pay cash. I'll keep this. It can be traced. Use this one instead. Don't answer unless you see it's me. *
answer: Anything else?

question: I love you.
answer: Emma's right. This sucks. Be goddamn careful.

question: I'm telling you, Clyde has someone * working with him. Someone on the outside.
answer: Who? Who could he have?

question: Somebody from his past. Could be * that spook we met on the stairs, * for all we know -- he'd know how to * plant this shit...
answer: Him? No--why would Clyde let him come talk to us?

question: To fuck with our heads? To get us to bring in our ADAs so he could blow them up?
answer: I--I don't know...

question: Jonas, think -- last few days, have * you used any ice? Any salt?
answer: I don't use salt--my cholesterol. Ice? Yeah--not long ago.

question: Before or after he was arrested?
answer: I don't remember! You track your * use of ice, Nick? You keep a daily * log?

question: Holy shit.
answer: Nice?

question: That stuff in your house -- it's all gone too far. I started this. I owe everybody at least one last try at defusing it.
answer: Interesting location you've chosen.

question: I thought we'd have some privacy.
answer: For what? A talk? Or... Maybe you've decided to take Detective Dunnigan's advice.

question: Be the perfect place for it. Outside the wall. Look like you were shot trying to escape.
answer: You have some kind of signal worked out? You scratch your nose and blam, I'm a goner?

question: Something like that.
answer: Might solve all your problems. What's stopping you? Afraid of the blowback?

question: No. It's to prove a point. Just because I have the power, doesn't mean I have to use it.
answer: Ah. Nice. Good one.

question: One can show mercy.
answer: Mercy. Right.

question: Yeah. So why don't you?
answer: I think we've come a little too far for that, haven't we, Nick? I mean, what do I say? Sorry, my bad? Which way to the execution chamber?

question: Don't give me that. Death doesn't scare you.
answer: Yeah, but...we're in the flow of this now. You cry havoc, you let slip the dogs of war, you go with * it. You don't just stop because * someone says hey wait. By then the dogs are dragging you.

question: Until one side admits defeat. What if I did that? What if I said... ...you were right. I was wrong. What if I say I should have prosecuted both men ten years ago?
answer: I'd say you're making progress. You should have, you know. Prosecuted both.

question: I'd have lost.
answer: With your head held high. And without any blame from me.

question: Yeah... She is? Great news. I'll stop on my way back. And Royce? Put some get- well flowers in her room, they sell 'em in the lobby. Thanks. Six hours in surgery.
answer: But she's okay -- good. Miss Lowell is a fine young woman. Oh, hey...your wife and little girl get out of town all right?

question: You asking that question makes me want to scratch my nose.
answer: Just a guess. It's what I would do. Get 'em out, make sure they're safe. C'mon. Like I'd ever have hurt them anyway.

question: No?
answer: There are limits. Even in war. I may be many things, Nick. But I'm not Clarence Darby. I'm not Rupert Ames. I'm not that kind of monster.

question: What kind are you?
answer: Not the kind who'd hurt your wife and child. Christ, look at me. Mine were my salvation -- then they were killed -- and all I had left was this. Life without them in this fucking charnel-house world. It hurt to lose them, didn't it? Your family. Even knowing they'd come back.

question: Yeah.
answer: Imagine knowing they wouldn't.

question: I can't. I can't imagine that. *
answer: Good. I envy you. For me, knowing * mine won't come back is the only thing that's crowded my thoughts for ten years. If I could take a rusty knife and cut out that part of my brain, I would.

question: I won't make any more deals with murderers. If hearing that makes a difference...if that was the point of all this...you've won.
answer: Counselor. I have no doubt, as we stand here, that you really believe that. I wish I could. Are we done? You gonna scratch your nose, or can I go?

question: ...tell Hansen we need hard info on those addresses...don't let the shell game on ownership title slow him down...at this point we'll take educated guesses...
answer: Hey.

question: Hey. Nice flowers. Thanks.
answer: How you doing?

question: This place has great drugs. Damn. I should've totaled my leg long ago. They're all dead?
answer: I'm afraid so. You're alive. That counts for a * lot. * * I'm sorry I put you in harm's way. *

question: It wasn't you. It was that son of a bitch. I hear he's threatened Jonas? *
answer: We're all over it. Jonas is safe -- * out of reach. *

question: Who's winning?
answer: Wanna sit in?

question: If I had my Braille set, I'd clean you out. Not much of a game if you have to tell me what my cards are.
answer: Right...sorry.

question: People forget. No worries. Enjoy your game, fellas. I'm good. Unfamiliar places take me a little longer. But I get there.
answer: Holler if you need anything. Okay, who's in, who's out...

question: Hey. Some legal team from the mayor * showed up here this morning. I hear * you're off the case. Told you they'd * scapegoat you, didn't I? Nick? You there? * Say you find a guy with a bad cocaine problem. Hungry ex-wives. Greedy mistress. Heavy gambling debts. * Say that guy's a veterinarian. You * hand him a million in cash, he'll * do what you ask. Especially if he's * looking to blow town for good...
answer: It was...inside the dog?

question: You own the vet, you own the dog. Explosive wasn't even that big. Stuff I use, it didn't have to be. Hidden in plain sight. That's my specialty. Haven't you figured that out yet? What's next for you? Mulling career options? I suppose law is out.
answer: I'm trying to get over my friend being dead. Aside from that, fuck you.

question: Fair enough. I'll miss you Nick. It was a good dance.
answer: Didn't bring your family back, though, did it? Has it made you feel better? All this? You done making your point?

question: We got the latest batch of background in. Hansen and the other guy did some good work here--
answer: Sarah. Give it a rest. It's over. We're done. I'm done. The mayor is nailing my coffin shut. The best thing you can do right now is distance yourself from me as much as you can -- see what you can salvage of your career.

question: This lists over fifty shit-value properties in industrial zones that nobody in their right mind would want to own -- stuff around chemical plants, factories. All are owned by Benson Clyde. Look at twenty-two.
answer: "Joe's Lube-and-Drive Garage." Went out of business in '94. Now why would Joe's extinct Lube- and-Shit Garage be of the slightest possible fucking interest to you, me, or anyone?

question: Dunnigan.
answer: Do we finish this tonight?

question: Nick? Jesus... Look. No hard feelings, but there is no "we." You're radioactive. I * can't even be seen talking to you...
answer: I know who he's got on the outside. I'll ask again. Do we finish this tonight?

question: All units. Subject vehicle is on the move. Everybody maintain distance. Hang back...hang back... Five and six, stick with that building in case he's trying to cowboy us. All other units, stay with the van...
answer: Where the hell is he going? You don't suppose Nomos Custodial * has a service contract with City Hall, do you?

question: Mr. Nomos! Ain't seen you around.
answer: Ted...had to get that vacation in. Visited my sister in the Keys...

question: Nice. Good for you.
answer: Hey, what's all that hoopla at the main entrance?

question: Mayor's got a big fuckin' thing. Thousand dollar a plate whatever. They say the Governor might come.
answer: I'll stay out of their way.

question: Alert the mayor's security team. * Evacuate those people upstairs -- * clear that ballroom, go!
answer: No!

question: No? What the fuck are you talking about, this could go off any second!
answer: He won't set it off until that room is full! People are still arriving, red carpet shit, that's at least another half hour!

question: I will not take that risk!
answer: You have to! If I'm him, I've rigged cameras in that ballroom -- live video feed -- first sign of an evacuation, I trigger the bomb. We have to think ahead of this fuck!

question: I came to talk. Guess who wasn't in his cell? Imagine my surprise.
answer: Imagine mine.

question: Beautiful how you played us. Getting yourself tossed into solitary -- * pre-rigged with exits from all five * cells. Whichever one we put you in, you had your bases covered. I thought I was such a bad-ass putting you down here. Turns out I was doing what you wanted.
answer: That's how you play. Make the other guy think it's his idea. You came to talk, so talk.

question: Been thinking. If I'd done things differently -- made different decisions from the start -- we wouldn't have gotten to this point.
answer: But it happened. And here we are.

question: Here we are. Your decisions put us here too. This mess is on both of us. *
answer: You want to hold hands? What's your point?

question: We can't change decisions we've made. We can only account for decisions we make from here. I know what mine will be. What about you? You gonna finish dialing that number, or what?
answer: If I don't? What are you offering?

question: You looking to deal?
answer: I'm willing to listen.

question: Okay, here's the deal. The deal is...there is no deal. I told you. No more deals with murderers. I'm sticking to that. That's my decision. It's what you * taught me. Strange as it sounds, * I'm grateful for the lesson. * Your turn. You make the right decision, I'll see what I can do for you. But the wrong decision is one you'll have to live with the rest of your life.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: Me too... ...because like I said, it's a decision you'll have to live with the rest of your life. Which at this point I figure is... ...another 35 seconds. Check mate.
answer: Well played.
